Java.info: My favorite language and the one I most often work with. I like it for its consistency and stability.

JavaScript.info: Like to work with it as it is very flexible, sometimes wired and funny.

PHP.info: Sometimes the easiest and fastest to use, even I don't like it inconsistency.

Groovy.info: Although I used it mainly in spock tests (and some gradle configs) I really like the power it gives over the typical java.

Python.info: I sometimes used it to quickly write some extension (e.g. for mercurial or skype) - nice to quickly prototype something.

Scala.info: Researched it few years ago and really liked the language and scala environment.

SQL.info: Powerful and useful - I used it for many years already.

Html.info: Understanding the DOM structure and what DOM is, used HTML for about 15 years now

CSS.info: I know how to use and tweak it :)

Sass.info: An eye opener for CSS issues, very simple and very useful same time.

ES6.info: Just started with it and I see the benefits over vanilla javascript.

Backbone.info: I like it for the level of control it gives to the developer even the cost is boilerplate code

React.info: I really like the idea of creating own 'tags' (something I always valued in JSP) and the way the library works

Twitter Bootstrap.info: I'm finally able to create a web page which looks acceptable good without loosing days to play with CSS

JEE.info: I'm not a fan of the standard as it is often overcomplicated or wrongly designed (e.g. JAAS)

Jboss-Wildfly.info: It's not my choice java web server but I was often working with it.

Tomcat.info: Much simpler than Jboss - doing it's job.

Apache.info: I'm able to configure vhosts for php or proxy for java web apps or modify headers.

Hibernate.info: I've spent many years with it and I could for example configure level 2 cache or add interceptors to monitor entity changes

Spring Environment.info: I started using it 11 years ago and I'm happy it evolves all the time. Heavily used the security module.

JAX-RS.info: I like the standard and used it many times in many projects, I think it's well definied and fairly simple.

JPA.info: Another standard which is well defined and simple. Almost alwayse used it with Hibernate, just once with google BigData

Docker.info: Very useful. I've not used it on Live environment yet, but I'm pretty impressed with versioning design.

MySql.info: I used it in many projects already but I don't feel like a dba for it

MongoDb.info: I've used it in my hobby project (including MapReduce functionality) and one commercial but never used it in real production, so I'm not aware of it's weakness. But I still really like it.

Dagger.info: Small and sharp, I also use it in small java web apps - for which Spring IOC is to heavy

Butterknife.info: Pretty useful and helps removes a lot of boilerplate code

Firebase.info: Only started with services it provides. I researched OCR, messaging and configuration modules

GreenDAO.info: I've chosen it over ORMLite solution, it's faster and simpler to use

Retrofit.info: Natural choice for android rest client, I've not write to many client methods yet

EventBus.info: It eased events sending and threads handling a lot

analytical mind.info: Always want to understand whole systems and how they work technically and in real live, often helping BA with fixing analysis gaps. Really like to find sources of difficult bugs.

creative.info: I like to suggest solutions and I like to create (both software and 'real' things)

fast learner.info: I really like to learn and doing it almost all the time in my free time

mentor.info: Always happy to introduce new people to the project, team or technology

good sense of humour.info: It's much better to work in happy place with happy people!
